intro: Test your knowledge of this week's Herald news!

questions.question: Brown professor and anthropologist Ieva Jusionyte was recently awarded a MacArthur grant worth how much?
questions.explanation: On Oct. 8, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation named Professor of International Security and Anthropology Ieva Jusionyte as a 2025 MacArthur Fellow. The fellowship, awarded yearly to between 20 and 30 recipients, is an $800,000 grant supporting “extraordinarily talented and creative individuals,” according to the foundation’s website.

questions.question: On Tuesday, the Brown Undergraduate Council of Students announced a referendum concerning what topic?
choices: A vote of no confidence in the board of student organizations
questions.explanation: The UCS announced a referendum asking students whether Brown ought to accept or reject the federal Compact for Academic Excellence in Higher Education on Oct. 1.

questions.question: How many Brown students took an entrepreneurship course last year?
questions.explanation: More than 1,664 students claimed a seat in one of Brown’s many entrepreneurship courses, an increase of 20% from last year. Students identified the Nelson Center for Entrepreneurship as one reason for this increase.

questions.question: When was the S/NC grading system established at Brown?
questions.explanation: The S/NC grading option, which was implemented along with the Open Curriculum in 1969, promotes “educational exploration and risk-taking,” wrote Gilda Mossadegh, deputy dean of the College for academic advising, in an email to The Herald.

questions.question: At least how many departments have had their Ph.D admissions paused for the 2026-27 academic year?
questions.explanation: As Brown sought to identify targets for University-wide budget cuts in the spring and summer, administrators notified leaders of at least six departments that admissions for their Ph.D. programs would be paused.

questions.question: How many miles did students walk in the “Walk Across Rhode Island” event on Oct. 12?
questions.explanation: Thirty miles, 12 hours and over $4,000 raised. This Sunday, nearly 200 students from eight schools walked across the length of Rhode Island to raise money for malaria prevention.

questions.question: When did the Korean Language Program’s celebration of Hangeul, the Korean alphabet, begin?
questions.explanation: On Sept. 29, the Korean Language Program began their annual week of events in celebration of Hangeul, the Korean alphabet. Over a thousand students interacted with a colorful truck — called the Hangeul Truck — by typing in English messages that were translated into Korean.

questions.question: In what field did Professor Peter Howitt win the Nobel Prize?
questions.explanation: Early Monday morning, Brown Professor Emeritus of Economics Peter Howitt was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences “for the theory of sustained growth through creative destruction,” according to a press release from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.

questions.question: Axel Brito ’26 is running for Providence City Council as a member of what political party?
questions.explanation: Brito, a 21-year-old Los Angeles native, is running as a Republican in the Ward 2 special election, which will fill a seat vacated by former City Councilor Helen Anthony.

questions.question: When was the last time Brown football defeated both URI and Bryant in the same year?
questions.explanation: The statement win at Bryant, combined with their upset against URI in the Governor’s Cup last week, gives Brown the right to call themselves unofficial state champions –– a feat they hadn’t accomplished in the preceding seven years.
